To simplify the expression, we first need to break down the square roots into their simplest form.

For $3\sqrt{12}$, we can break down $\sqrt{12}$ into $\sqrt{4} \cdot \sqrt{3}$, which simplifies to $2\sqrt{3}$. So, $3\sqrt{12}$ becomes $3(2\sqrt{3}) = 6\sqrt{3}$.

For $2\sqrt{27}$, we can break down $\sqrt{27}$ into $\sqrt{9} \cdot \sqrt{3}$, which simplifies to $3\sqrt{3}$. So, $2\sqrt{27}$ becomes $2(3\sqrt{3}) = 6\sqrt{3}$.

Now, we can simplify the expression:

$3\sqrt{12} - 2\sqrt{27} = 6\sqrt{3} - 6\sqrt{3} = 0$
